column1: 2014AGUFM.P13D3841G|2014|Connecting Returned Apollo Soils and Remote Sensing: Application to the Diviner Lunar Radiometer|Greenhagen
column14: D. A.|AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts|||P13D|The Diviner Lunar Radiometer
column18: thermal infrared observations of an airless body. The Moon
column19: which is the most accessible member of this most abundant class of solar system objects
column20: is also the only body for which we have extraterrestrial samples with known spatial context. Here we present the results of a comprehensive study to reproduce an accurate simulated lunar environment
column21: evaluate the most appropriate sample and measurement conditions
column22: collect thermal infrared spectra of a representative suite of Apollo soils
column23: and correlate them with Diviner observations of the lunar surface. It has been established that thermal infrared spectra measured in a simulated lunar environment (SLE) are significantly altered from spectra measured under terrestrial conditions. The data presented here were collected at the University of Oxford Simulated Lunar Environment Chamber (SLEC). In SLEC
column24: the lunar environment is simulated by: (1) pumping the chamber to vacuum pressures (<10-4 mbar) sufficient to simulate lunar heat transport processes within the sample
column25: (2) cooling the chamber with liquid nitrogen to simulate radiation to the cold space environment
column26: and (3) heating the samples with heaters and lamp to set-up thermal gradients similar to those experienced in the upper hundreds of microns of the lunar surface. A comprehensive suite of experiments were conducted using different sample preparation and heating conditions on Apollo soils 15071 (maria) and 67701 (highland) and compared the results to Diviner noontime data to select the optimal experimental conditions. Additional thermal infrared measurements in optimized SLE were made of 10084 (A11 - LM)
column34: and 70181 (A17 - LM).The Diviner dataset includes all six Apollo sites at approximately 200 m spatial resolution. We find that analyses of Diviner observations of individual sampling stations and SLE measurements of returned Apollo soils show good agreement
column35: while comparisons to thermal infrared reflectance under terrestrial conditions do not agree well
column36: which underscores the need for SLE measurements and validates the Diviner compositional dataset.

column1: 2013AGUFM.P54B..05S|2013|Lunar Regolith Maturity Controlled By Ilmenite Content And Micro-Meteor Flux Variability|Schmitt
column2: H. H.|AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts|||P54B|Synthesis of Is/FeO maturity indexes for Apollo 17 regolith samples in the valley of Taurus-Littrow on the Moon indicate that high levels of ilmenite in the samples significantly reduces the level of this indicator of space exposure. The analysis
column3: along with consideration of regolith glass characteristics
column4: also discloses that micro-meteor fluxes vary over geologic time
column5: presumably in response to significant impact events in the Asteroid Belt. Surface samples of ilmenite-poor
column6: silicate-rich regolith have about 80-90% higher maturity indexes than surface samples of ilmenite-rich
column7: basaltic regolith of comparable exposure. For comparison of the history of various regolith exposures to the space environment
column9: the youngest large area stratigraphic unit
column10: provides a specific time horizon. For at least the last ~110 million years
column11: the currently estimated age of the light mantle avalanche
column12: most near surface (upper 1-5cm) regolith has had approximately the same exposure to micro-meteors. The surface of the largely ilmenite-rich basalt fill in the valley has been exposed to space at least as long or possibly 30 million years longer than the light mantle
column13: based on exposure ages for large boulder ejecta in the Camelot cluster of craters. High apparent maturity (Is/FeO >80)
column15: exists only on three types of regolith surfaces: (1) the North Massif apron (e.g.
column20: 72150). Only intermediate to low maturity (Is/FeO <60) has developed in surface regolith overlying high titanium basalt (e.g.
column21: 70181). TiO2/TiO2+FeO ratios provide a good measure of original ilmenite content
column22: ilmenite being the only quantitatively significant titanium-bearing mineral in the regolith. Those ratios for samples showing high and intermediate apparent maturity are about 0.35 and 0.25
column25: 77260) exposed at Shorty Crater as a unit stratigraphically overlying the orange ash
column26: has exceptionally low maturity (8% agglutinates and Is/FeO = 5) but an unusually high amount of "ropy" glass (14-18%). (Ropy glass normally constitutes less than on percent of new Taurus-Littrow regolith. It forms within fresh impact craters as a result of macro-meteor impacts
column27: but the current flux of micro-meteors disaggregates such glass within a million years or less.) The light mantle avalanche deposit protected this ancient regolith unit at Shorty Crater for at up to 90 million years prior to the Shorty impact 14-17 million years ago. A significant micro-meteor flux cannot have existed during the formation of this ancient regolith or it would have a higher maturity index and little or no ropy glass. Variable maturities observed in core samples from elsewhere in the valley of Taurus-Littrow may be the result of either variable mirco-meteor flux or variable exposure during periods of moderate flux or a combination of both.

column1: 2012epsc.conf..297F|2012|Solar Reflectance Measurements of Apollo Lunar Soils|Foote
column16: C.|European Planetary Science Congress 2012|||EPSC2012|The moon is the one planetary object from which we have returned samples. The goal of this work is to analyze and understand the solar reflectance of the Moon. Our approach is to compare Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter (LRO) Diviner orbital solar albedo measurements at the Apollo soil sample sites with laboratory bidirectional reflectance measurements. CAPTEM provided us with five representative lunar soil samples: a typical low albedo mare sample (10084
column18: a low titanium basaltic sample with impact breccias (12001
column21: a high albedo lunar highlands soil (68810 & 61141
column22: Apollo 16) and an Apollo 17 soil sample (70181). The laboratory and Diviner datasets provide complementary and independent insights into the photometric properties of the lunar surface. We have made the most extensive set of laboratory bidirectional measurements of lunar soil to date and have successfully fit photometric models to the laboratory data.

The absence of such differences indicates that the isotopic compositions for bulk samples are dominated by a light-isotope-rich surface component. Data for size separates of lunar soils also confirm the surface correlation of Cu and Zn

The size of the isotopic fractionation inferred for the surface component in the soils is 3× smaller than predicted by a published model of sputtering primarily by solar particles. At the same time
column45: the observed fractionation is larger than predicted by calculations based on a model of micrometeorite impact heating and hydrodynamic quenching. Because impact heating appears unable to explain the observations
column46: we conclude that sputtering must be important even though samples with very large isotopic fractionation of Cu and Zn have not yet been found.
